subject: G-Men
event:
Almost caught up on my football.  Last night we watched the Giants / Seahawks game.

Holy crap.  What a beating.  Not exactly the most suspenseful contest we've seen this season, but there is a certain rough pleasure in watching your guys just whale the tar out of another team.  And it certainly beats being on the losing end of such of a pounding, as the G-Men were several times last year down the stretch.

Honestly, it looked to me as if the Seahawks just stopped playing about halfway through the second quarter.  If so, that's worrisome for you Seattle fans.  I remember when Pete Carroll coached the Jets.  Only one season.  The team just quit on him after the infamous Marino fake spike game.  Maybe Carroll really is better suited to the college game.

I have to believe that Seattle is not nearly as bad as they looked.  I'd like to believe that the Giants are as good as they looked... but I don't, not really.

It was a terrific game for Eli and his receivers, though.  That long TD pass to Nicks was a thing of beauty, as was the thread-the-needle pass to the double-coevered Kevin Boss.  And the RBs kicked some ass too -- Ahmad Bradshaw, Brandon Jacobs, even Danny Ware.  Though by the time that Ware came in, the 'Hawks were playing two-handed touch.  The Giants D also looked great, though given how quickly the score got lop-sided, we probably should have had more sacks.  Poor Whitehurst was passing on almost every play.

Kudos to Tom Coughlin too.  To my mind, he coached the blowout exactly right.  He took out Eli and the starting RBs right at the beginning of the fourth quarter, and instead of trying to run up the score he just ran the ball straight into the line with Ware for play after play after play to chew up the clock and end the massacre.  Even at the end, with the Giants inside the Seahawk ten, he had Rosenfels kneel down four times rather than push in another TD.  That, to my mind, is sportsmanship... and stands in sharp contrast to the crap that Evil Little Bill was pulling when he had his 18-1 team and set all those scoring records.  Let the other guy leave with a little dignity.

Still have Giants/ Cowboys II and Jets/ Browns to watch.  Then we'll be caught up.  But of course there are two new games tomorrow.  

Meanwhile, in Westeros, I am wrestling with krakens.

comments.article: Allow me to be the first to say: get kraken!

That was a painful one to watch brother. Glad you were on the right side for enjoying that one. I believe I turned it off about halftime and went back to Westeros, ala AFFC. Happy Trails George!

Brandt
comments.subject: Greetings from Seattle

comments.article: Can't wait until you get all caught up. Then the serious, or not so serious prognostication can begin.

That week the Seahawks had:

3 starting DLs out
2 Starting OLs out
Starting QB out
2 starting WRs out

...and a couple of other misc. injuries. The Giants basically played a really good college team that day. Not saying the Seahwaks would have won, but it would have at least been a game instead of the thorough thrashing I watched. Oh, and I watched all 4 torturous quarters.

The consensus about Pete Carroll in the Seattle Camp is that he's doing an excellent job of marshaling at best mediocre talent into being mostly competitive. I did a fairly in depth analysis on that game and believe it or not, the players were actually trying on D in the fourth. Sad, right?

Still we'll probably win our terrible division and lose to the wildcard, probably to the same Saints who are going to beat us tomorrow.

p.s. Thanks for the calamari.

Excellent points. The Seahawks seem to be back on the right track. A good off-season draft and free-agent hiring along with health and next season should see this team return to it's former glory.

The Giants have been making hay by winning games after knocking out the starting QB. I won't say they are lucky, but playing against a limited offense hides some serious flaws.

I think your "jabs" at Belichick are in poor taste, as there have been plenty of teams over the years that have run up the score just like the Patriots have done before.
I hope the Jets and Giants enjoy second place in their respective divisions!

Anways...
Can't wait for the book! :D
comments.subject: Ehh...

comments.article: As a Patriots fan, it is totally heartwarming to know that Belichick's that far inside his head. I'm also well aware that it doesn't have anything to do with morality; it's simply that Belichick used to coach for both the Jets and the Giants. It's got to be totally galling to see that much coaching talent reject both of your favorite teams.
comments.subject: Re: Ehh...

comments.article:
That, to my mind, is sportsmanship... and stands in sharp contrast to the crap that Evil Little Bill was pulling when he had his 18-1 team and set all those scoring records.

Thank you! It seems like I'm always surrounded by New England fans, and this is exactly what I mean when I say I can't stand them. It's not that they're good: It's that they're classless.
Even some of the biggest Pats fans I know think evil little Bill is too big for his britches and would rather see him gone.

Those are the types of fans you'd rather see routing for some other team.

No matter how he left the Jets, the guy is a football coaching genius.

comments.upictitle: the Antisocial Little Ice Queen: TXT: Well too late now
comments.article: Our football team may not be so great, but our roller derby team is AWESOME.

comments.upictitle: Mr Geddy Lee (though not really): bond
comments.article: I loathe all New York sports teams as a matter of principle, so I may be disagreeing with you for more than one reason. In any case, I dislike running up the score in college ball. That shows a lack of sportsmanship. However, everyone in professional football gets paid fairly well to go out there and perform. You don't like getting forty-plus points hung on you? Play better defense. You want someone to worry about your feelings? Find a different line of work, pal.

I'm afraid I agree and disagree at the same time. Weird, right?

On a team that has no developing talent and no starters to protect from injury, then absolutely run the score as high as you can. You would be hard pressed to find that team in the NFL.

A coach should take the opportunity to play some of his fringe payers and give them a chance to prove themselves. That coach should also be protecting his star players from a pointless injury during garbage time.

So while the losing team has no business whining about running up the score because of injured pride, any NFL head coach who continues to put the hammer down during a massive blowout is being classless douche, because it is not the best move for the team, merely the best move for that coach's ego.
Don't know much 'bout Football (actually, being European, not a b.d. thing) but I hope them Krakens will feel like the Seahawks after the game you commented on... Good wrestling!

Somehow I don't think most of the characters in Westeros would buy into your sportsmanship speech. I can just picture Jamie choking on his wine for a second in laughter. But I do share your hatred of Evil Little Bill and am also a Giants fan.
Glad to hear you are enjoying your games, good sir. You will need the mental and physical respite to wrestle those krakens. Here's hoping you make us all some sushi out of them!

"Running up the score" is a meaningless phrase on the professional level. With professionals on both sides of the ball (except in Buffalo), if you don't want the other guy to score, then STOP HIM ffs.

The most concerning thing about the Giants is their terrific lack of sportsmanship. How many of those wins that you have watched came after the Giants' defense sent a key player on the opposing team's offense to the locker room for medical treatment? In my mind, too many to be a coincidence. They are playing dirty and I find it disgusting.
comments.subject: Giants

comments.article:
The Giants hit hard but no one who knows anything about football has ever accused them of being dirty. You're just revealing your own ignorance of the game with your "disgust." Have you even watched the hits in question? All clean.

There are teams in the NFL that skirt pretty close to the line, and certainly there are individual players who are cheapshot artists (Flozell Adams comes to mind), but the G-Men are not coached that way.
comments.subject: Re: Giants

comments.article:
But then again, most of Flozell's hits are "clean" too...he just adds a little something extra. It is starting to look like Umenyiora is doing the same. Sure, it is a rough sport, and one that I am not at all "ignorant" of, but there is a major difference between tackling someone and leveling them.

Your reply is understandable though, I am a huge homer when it comes to the Broncos. Unless you are talking about Mcdaniels, or Maroney, in which case, I'm with you.
comments.subject: Re: Giants

comments.article: Flozell Adams is an offensive tackle, so he shouldn't be making any hits, 'clean' or not.
comments.subject: Re: Giants

comments.article:
Did you happen to notice the play in the 2nd quarter where Vick ran up the middle? Rolle sniffed it out and made a great play on Vick. But...Rolle went low and while Vick was going down, Umenyiora CLEARLY went for a headshot that Vick just barely ducked.

You can be condescending and insult my intelligence (your blog, your rules), that's fine. I don't play that game. And it has no bearing whatsoever on what I saw last night, and all season, for that matter.
comments.subject: Re: Giants

comments.article: Carroll took the Seattle job ahead of getting banned by the NCAA during the USC investigation.
comments.subject: Carroll not wanted in NCAA

comments.article:
Or, he got paid a crap-ton of cash to prove that he could cut it in the NFL by basically getting full control of an NFL richest franchise.

USC got hosed, and I f'in hate USC so I am not biased. Those kids should be getting paid to play for all the money they generate the for the school and for the NCAA. Fair market value, please.

What is sad is how choosy the NCAA is with its enforcement, since the "problem" is certainly not an isolated one. Taking away a national championship and a Heisman without a Delorean powered by 1.28 GW of power is impossible anyway. We all watched the game. We all know what happened. If you can prove to me that Reggie getting a nice-ish car (seriously, it was like a '97 Impala) and a modest house for his parents from people who had no affiliation with USC somehow made him play better, then I cede the point. Perhaps being able to afford healthy food rather than ramen noodles made him bench more, I don't know.

What Reggie Bush did was akin to getting a bank loan from a private citizen based on a promise of future earned revenues. The NCAA's archaic position on this type of thing is a big reason why athletes declare for the draft early. Everyone is getting paid but them. How is that fair?

Why should these guys be risking injury with no compensation? And don't give me that tired old argument that the free education is compensation, because most of the star players barely go to class. The players know why they're there. The schools know why they're there. The fans know why they're there. Let them earn what they can. Regulate it, make it above board, and you'll have yourselves a fair system. (Oh and we need a playoff.)

/rant
comments.subject: Re: Carroll not wanted in NCAA

comments.article:
I agree completely. Something needs to change in the college game. Either the players should get paid, or the schools shouldn't. I have heard people argue that paying the players would ruin the "purity" of college football. Purity? Really?

Coach's compensation is also way out of control. There needs to be a cap...how about limiting coach's salaries to whatever the president of the university makes?
comments.subject: Re: Carroll not wanted in NCAA

comments.article:
Meanwhile, in Westeros, I am wrestling with krakens.

Best news I've received in a long time. Looking forward to it all =)
